{"aid": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2505.04550v1", "title": "An imageless magnetic resonance framework for fast and cost-effective
  decision-making", "summary": "Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) is the gold standard for non-invasive tissue
abnormality detection, yet hardware complexity, long acquisition times, and
high cost limit rapid screening and point-of-care use. We introduce Imageless
Magnetic Resonance Diagnosis (IMRD), a framework that bypasses k-space sampling
and image reconstruction by analyzing raw one-dimensional MR signals. IMRD
integrates (i) optimized pulse sequences for time-domain contrast, (ii) minimal
low-field hardware, and (iii) AI-driven pattern recognition to answer clinical
closed queries and quantify lesion burden. As a proof of concept, we simulate
multiple sclerosis lesions in silico within brain phantoms and deploy two
approximately 3 s protocols (single-spoke and gradientless). A 1D convolutional
neural network achieves AUC close to 0.95 for lesion detection and R2 close to
0.99 for volume estimation. We also perform robustness tests under reduced
signal-to-noise ratio, partial signal omission, and relaxation-time
variability. By reframing MR signals as direct diagnostic metrics, IMRD paves
the way for fast, low-cost MR screening and monitoring in resource-limited
environments.", "main_category": "physics.med-ph", "categories": "physics.med-ph", "published": "2025-05-07T16:31:26Z"}
